snippet: New Yorkers’ longevity rose over the past 20 years, the study says, citing factors like declines in AIDS deaths, homicide and smoking-related illnesses, along with immigrants, who tend to have lower mortality rates.
abstract: University of Pennsylvania's Population Studies Center study shows New Yorkers’ longevity rose over past 20 years, stunning increase; cites factors including declines in AIDS deaths, homicide and smoking-related illnesses, along with influx of immigrants, who tend to have lower mortality rates.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers’ longevity rose over the past 20 years, the study says, citing factors like declines in AIDS deaths, homicide and smoking-related illnesses, along with immigrants, who tend to have lower mortality rates.

headline.main: Life Expectancy of New Yorkers Rises With Influx of Immigrants, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Life Expectancy in City Rises With More Immigrants, a Study Finds
